[1m[22m
I feel like this is kind of a rite of passage anime. A typical trap where, the first episode seems fine, so you watch one, and then you have committed yourself to watching more. You slowly but steadily realise that you have made a huge mistake, but you keep watching episode after episode, hoping something will change. And then, you reach the final episode, which gives the most satisfying feeling I have ever felt watching a show. It makes it all worthwhile.

This anime received high reviews from me because of how much of a 'WOW' factor it had when it was over. The story itself is a slow building one that leads you into a false sense of security. The ability to completely catch a viewer who has seen all types of anime and can read the feel of them pretty good such as the character personalities, its typical flow, and a bunch of other stuff is just, well it makes me feel like an arrogant fool. Legit my little 'No anime can fully surprise me' attitude was gone in an instant. But the point is if you want your mind rocked and you like drama on all scales: extreme to insignificant this is the anime for you. If not, stand clear after all Hell hath no fury like a women scorned.

I've been hearing so much about this anime saying like, 'Don't watch it!', 'It will piss you off', or 'I hate it, worst anime ever!' How is that NOT going to get me curious and watch it anyway? So, I decided to watch the anime and see why everyone hates it. Things were totally normal at episodes 3 and below. My thoughts were, 'Okay, this is like any other harem. There's more than one attractive girl around this guy.' So, I kept on watching. But then, the guy does some awful unforgiving thing that would consider him a douchbag. Well, here's my review--

[1mç§ã¯ã“ã®ã‚¢ãƒ‹ãƒ¡ã«ã¤ã„ã¦ã€ã€Œãã‚Œã‚’è¦‹ã¦ã¯ã„ã‘ãªã„ï¼ã€ã€ã€Œãã‚Œã¯ã‚ãªãŸã‚’æ€’ã‚‰ã›ã‚‹ã€ã€ã€Œãã‚Œã¯å«Œã„ã€æœ€æ‚ªã®ã‚¢ãƒ‹ãƒ¡ã€ã¨è¨€ã£ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ ã¨ã«ã‹ããã‚Œã¯ç§ã«å¥½å¥‡å¿ƒã‚’æŒãŸã›ã€ãã‚Œã‚’è¦‹å®ˆã‚‹ã¤ã‚‚ã‚Šã¯ã‚ã‚Šã¾ã›ã‚“ã‹ï¼Ÿ ã ã‹ã‚‰ã€ç§ã¯ã‚¢ãƒ‹ãƒ¡ã‚’è¦‹ã¦ã€ãªãœèª°ã‚‚ãŒãã‚Œã‚’å«Œã†ã®ã‚’è¦‹ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã«ã—ã¾ã—ãŸã€‚ ã‚¨ãƒ”ã‚½ãƒ¼ãƒ‰3ä»¥ä¸‹ã§ã¯ç‰©äº‹ã¯å®Œå…¨ã«æ­£å¸¸ã ã£ãŸã€‚ ç§ã®è€ƒãˆã¯ã€Œå¤§ä¸ˆå¤«ã§ã™ã€ã“ã‚Œã¯ä»–ã®é¦¬ã®ã‚ˆã†ãªã‚‚ã®ã§ã™ã€‚ ã“ã®ç”·ã®å‘¨ã‚Šã«ã¯1äººä»¥ä¸Šã®é­…åŠ›çš„ãªå¥³ã®å­ãŒã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ ã ã‹ã‚‰ç§ã¯è¦‹å®ˆã£ãŸã€‚ ã—ã‹ã—ã€ãã®å¾Œã€å½¼ã¯å½¼ã‚’ãƒ€ãƒƒã‚·ãƒ¥â€‹â€‹ãƒãƒƒã‚°ã¨è¦‹ãªã™æã‚ã—ã„éé…·ãªã“ã¨ã‚’ã—ã¦ã„ã¾ã™ã€‚ ã•ã¦ã€ç§ã®ãƒ¬ãƒ“ãƒ¥ãƒ¼ã§ã™ - [22m
[1m(Watashi wa kono anime ni tsuite,`sore o mitehaikenai!',`Sore wa anata o okora seru',`soreha-girai, saiaku no anime' to itte imasu. This story is your typical harem story but with many dark twists to it. It begins with your typical love triangle between the main character, Makoto (a HUGE douche) and two other girls, Kotonoha and Sekai. I have to say, the ending was quite satisfying. Sekai gets Makoto and Kotonoha together but quickly develops feelings for him. As the story progresses, it gets more unlikely or unrealistic since people are (as I have said before) making stupid or ridiculous decisions. When Sekai said 'i'll give you practice.' I was thinking '...wow...' First time I have ever heard of an offer like that. The story just keeps spiraling downwards and downwards. It was quite dull most of the time until one of those dodgy decisions pops up, then it returns to being dull again. I have to give it some points for SOME realism and its dark feeling but not much. So as I have said, I didn't particularly like the story which is one of the main reasons I came into this, other reason including the ending.

There was some parts of the series that I did enjoy such as laughing at some of the situations some of the characters were in and the ending. But most of the time, this was overshadowed at my annoyance at how stupid some of the characters can be and (I cannot stress this enough) some of the decisions the characters made. There was a certain point where I just got sick of the repetitiveness of the decisions that the only reason I kept watching was for the ending. The only things I was remotely interested in was the initial love triangle and the ending (I have mentioned the ending a lot...). I eventually just cracked up out how insane and stupid some of the characters turned out to be. So it was relatively enjoyable at first but that died as the series progressed.

In conclusion, the bad parts of the series outweigh many of the enjoyable/average parts that I found in this series.To sum it all up, I enjoyed the first part of the series because it was the most realistic and the ending because it was the most satisfying part of the anime. I didn't enjoy the repetitiveness of the stupid decisions and the unrealistic turn it had taken when it became a love square, pentagon or hexagon. None of this was helped by the mediocre sound and art. There is one thing I can take from this anime which is the most obvious point ever, don't cheat on your partner. Although, I highly doubt that if you do, it could lead to this. So yeah, I didn't really like School Days.

The story is about a trio of friends, Makoto, Sekai and Kotonoha. Makoto appears to be a normal high school boy. He has a crush on the girl he rides the train to school with and one day decides to take a picture of her, believing in the 'Cellphone Charm', which states that if you take a picture of someone you like and nobody finds out, then you will be together with that person. Makoto's new seat mate, Sekai, see the picture and decides to help Makoto. She introduces him to Kotonoha, and continues to support him, but soon she starts to develop feelings towards Makoto as well.

Excellent. The soundtrack blended with the mood of the show well, turning from a few whimsical melodies in the earlier episodes, to melancholic, sorrow tunes in the middle episodes; and in the end, the music became so sad that you will weep just by hearing the soundtrack alone. For the vocal songs part, we have a few memorable inserts, particularly 'Kioku no Umi' (which I also enjoyed a lot), 'Namida no Riyuu' (used in the turning point of the series - the raining scene), and of course 'Kanashimino Mukou e' used in the final ending. The OP also deserved a special mention, although I did not enjoy it as much as the other songs.

Since School Days is a deconstruction of the harem-high school genre, rather than saying that the characters received any form of development throughout the show, I would suggest that the characters received a lot of 'anti-development' (yes, it's a new word I invented). Indeed, you can see Makoto turning from just a normal high schooler to a pervert who does nothing but having sex all day. Kotonoha turned from an innocent young woman to a love-craze. Sekai... Ughh. She was as bad as she was throughout the whole show.

Ah, I've watched a few anime in my days but of those I watched that stood out there are only a few. Sadly however School Days was my all time most hated anime. After finishing it I was depressed for an entire week (that has never happened to me in my life before). I feel like I was abused watching the show unravel as thing went from bad to worse and ending in such a ludicrous way. If there is a 'worst cast ever created'-award, School Days would deserve it more than anything else. It might be possible that you start feeling hatred towards every single person that has gotten a little bit of screen time. They are overdrawn, dumb, personality less, anime cliche deep to the pores and smell like pure bullshit. Ok, we are talking about the harem genre which isn't known for having the smartest or the greatest cast within their shows but School Days is almost outstanding in the genre itself for being even worse than anything else. The cherry of the cake here is Makoto - the main protagonist. His innocent, shy appearance during the first episodes is faker than the noses of the most female Hollywood stars nowadays - every single episode will make you wanting Makoto to get a deadly genital disease or something due his perverted and reckless behavior. It's like his brain moves bit for bit from his head to the lower part of his torso. The girls aren't better - they don't think and strip down their panties without even asking.
